description: Let f(m) = smallest prime that divides k^2 + k + m for k = 0,1,2,...; sequence gives smallest m >= 2 such that f(m) is the n-th prime, or -1 if no such m exists.
comments: Chris Nash (see the Prime Puzzles link) has shown that such an m always exists.For n>2, least odd number d such that the Legendre symbol (1-4d/prime(k)) = -1 for k = 2,...,n, but not for n+1. See A060392. - _T. D. Noe_, Apr 19 2004
references: Fung and Williams, Quadratic polynomials with high density of primes, Mathematics of Computation, Vol. 55, 1990.
R. F. Lukes, C. D. Patterson and H. C. Williams, Numerical sieving devices: their history and some applications. Nieuw Arch. Wisk. (4) 13 (1995), no. 1, 113-139. Math. Rev. 96m:11082
example: k^2 + k + 2 takes the values 2, 4, 8, 14, ... for k = 0,1,2,...; the smallest prime divisor of these numbers is 2, so f(2) = 2.
mathematica: (* This program is not convenient beyond a(24) *) a[1] = 2; a[2] = 3; a[n_] := For[d = 1, True, d = d+2, If[And @@ (# == -1 & /@ Table[JacobiSymbol[1 - 4d, Prime[k]], {k, 2, n}]) && JacobiSymbol[1 - 4d, Prime[n+1]] != -1, Return[d]]]; Table[Print[an = a[n]]; an, {n, 1, 24}] (* _Jean-Fran√ßois Alcover_, Oct 14 2013, after _T. D. Noe_ *)
crossrefs: Cf. A060392-A060398. A060393 gives associated values of k.
author: Luis Rodriguez-Torres (ludovicusmagister(AT)yahoo.com), Apr 03 2001
